elements.content: Porous pillared bilayer open coordination polymer {[Cd(bpp)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)2 ·(H2O)6} n 1 (Fc = ferrocene) and 3D porous coordination polymer {[Cd(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)4} n 2 have been assembled from Cd(NO3)2, ferrocene-1,1′-disulfonate, and bridging ligands 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) or 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy). Both of them show very special adsorption properties to copper salts. Along with the increase in the solution concentration of Cu(NO3)2, the percentage of adsorbed copper ions falls, but the percentage of exchanged central cadmium ions and the amount of adsorbed copper ions rises. In dilute solution, there mainly exists metal ion sorption, whereas both ion sorption and exchange are in charge of the whole progress in strong solution. Meanwhile, such materials could be used as ideal metal ion adsorbent toward some other metal cations, including of Pb2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+. However, when all these metal ions coexist in a mixture solution, the two ferrocenyl complexes selectively adsorb large amounts of only Pb2+ (for 1, 88.54%; for 2, 75.80%) and Cu2+ (for 1, 90.94%; for 2, 79.45%). Ion sorption and central cadmium ion exchange might be considered as being dominated by the coordination ability of metal ions to free functional groups, ionic radii of adsorbed metal ions, and the solution concentration of adsorbed metal salts. On the basis of the recognition of ion exchange, the center metal ion-exchange product of 2, {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)4} n 3, could be obtained by ion-exchange-induced single crystal to single crystal transformation.

elements.content: Two porous inorganic polymeric metal ferrocene-1,1′-disulfonates {[Cd(bpp)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)2·(H2))6} n 1 and {[Cd(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)4} n 2 (bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine, bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane, Fc = ferrocene) were schemed out, and their ion sorption and exchange behaviors were tested at room temperature. On the basis of the recognition of ion exchange, the ion-exchange product of 2, {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)4} n 3, could be obtained by ion-exchange-induced single crystal to single crystal transformation. This study has profound significance in providing a useful channel in exploration of new metal ion adsorbents.

On the basis of the recognition of ion exchange, the ion-exchange product of 2, {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]⋅(CH3OH)4} n  3, could be obtained by ion-exchange-induced single crystal to single crystal transformation. This study has profound significance in providing a useful channel in exploration of new metal ion adsorbents.

elements.content: MOFs with porous structures are an interesting target for chemical synthesis and crystal engineering because of their great potential application in environmental and industrial processes. These porous materials were constructed by various rigid organic bidentate ligands containing pyridine rings, dicarboxylate, phosphonate, and sulfonate as spacers and metal cores as connectors. A significant feature of these frameworks is their large well-defined pore shape and pore size. The character has significant applications in ion exchange, gas storage, and separation. Ion exchange of these materials is achieved directly by suspending such frameworks in a solution containing metal salts. The search for similar ion-exchange materials with improved properties has been performed in recent years. For example, Lehn and his co-workers have studied the anion inclusion and exchange both in and out of the inner cavities of multicomponent cylindrical nanoarchitectures. Literatures concerning ion-exchange properties of open framework chalcogenides have also been reported by Kanatzidis. Heterodinuclear metal complexes could be easily prepared through ion-exchange reaction. Furthermore, recent documents have also referred to the research on the ion-exchange properties of the two-dimensional barium sulfonate network and other layered phosphates and disulfonamide complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

MOFs with porous structures are an interesting target for chemical synthesis and crystal engineering because of their great potential application in environmental and industrial processes. These porous materials were constructed by various rigid organic bidentate ligands containing pyridine rings, dicarboxylate, phosphonate, and sulfonate as spacers and metal cores as connectors. A significant feature of these frameworks is their large well-defined pore shape and pore size. The character has significant applications in ion exchange, gas storage, and separation. Ion exchange of these materials is achieved directly by suspending such frameworks in a solution containing metal salts. The search for similar ion-exchange materials with improved properties has been performed in recent years. For example, Lehn and his co-workers have studied the anion inclusion and exchange both in and out of the inner cavities of multicomponent cylindrical nanoarchitectures. Literatures concerning ion-exchange properties of open framework chalcogenides have also been reported by Kanatzidis. Heterodinuclear metal complexes could be easily prepared through ion-exchange reaction. Furthermore, recent documents have also referred to the research on the ion-exchange properties of the two-dimensional barium sulfonate network and other layered phosphates and disulfonamide complexes.

elements.content: Many MOFs with porous structures also exhibit excellent potential application in gas sorption and seperation. Recent advances in the area of functional zeolite materials show that zeolites can be used as metal ion adsorbents. Zeolite’s sorption characteristics to transition metal cations demonstrate that the table porous materials have potential applications as highly selective ion adsorbents. Moreover, the sorption properties of a zeolite analogue coordination polymer with amine and group I metal salts has further testified the ion sorption behavior of MOFs. Some other literatures have touched on the use of MOFs with porous structures in binding metals ions. Thus, we believe that MOFs with porous structures can also be utilized as metal ions adsorbents.
elements.clean_text: Many MOFs with porous structures also exhibit excellent potential application in gas sorption and seperation. Recent advances in the area of functional zeolite materials show that zeolites can be used as metal ion adsorbents. Zeolite's sorption characteristics to transition metal cations demonstrate that the table porous materials have potential applications as highly selective ion adsorbents. Moreover, the sorption properties of a zeolite analogue coordination polymer with amine and group I metal salts has further testified the ion sorption behavior of MOFs. Some other literatures have touched on the use of MOFs with porous structures in binding metals ions. Thus, we believe that MOFs with porous structures can also be utilized as metal ions adsorbents.

elements.content: If porous MOFs served as metal ion adsorbents, the ion sorption might involve physical sorption and chemical sorption. In the progress of chemical sorption, metal ions must interact with ligands, and the interaction closely associates with ion-exchange properties and may result in ion exchange, i.e., ion sorption of porous MOFs always take place simultaneously along with ion exchange. These performances accord well with the requirements of potential ion-removal materials. The open framework chalcogenide (NH4)4In12Se20 has also been used for heavy metal ion capture and ion exchange.
elements.clean_text: If porous MOFs served as metal ion adsorbents, the ion sorption might involve physical sorption and chemical sorption. In the progress of chemical sorption, metal ions must interact with ligands, and the interaction closely associates with ion-exchange properties and may result in ion exchange, i.e., ion sorption of porous MOFs always take place simultaneously along with ion exchange. These performances accord well with the requirements of potential ion-removal materials. The open framework chalcogenide (NH4)4In12Se20 has also been used for heavy metal ion capture and ion exchange.

elements.content: Our strategy for creating room-temperature metal ion adsorbents and exchangers utilizes inorganic polymeric cadmium ferrocene-1,1′-disulfonates because MOFs constructed by aryl sulfonates can shape porous structures, which have multiple dimensions and variant topologies with free functional groups. In virtue of the unsaturated sulfonate groups, metal sulfonates might have secondary coordination ability to recognize metal ions. On the basis of these recognition, we created a scheme of two nanoporous cadmium ferrocene-1,1′-disulfonates {[Cd(bpp)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)2·(H2O)6} n 1 and {[Cd(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)4} n 2. They show highly selectivity to various divalent metal ions at room temperature, and metal ion sorption take place simultaneously with ion exchange. The solution concentration of metal ions affects the ion sorption and exchange behavior. A possible mechanism of ion sorption and exchange in porous MOFs is proposed. According to this mechanism, the center metal ion-exchange product {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)4}n 3 was obtained via ion-exchange-induced single crystal to single crystal transformation (see Scheme ).

In virtue of the unsaturated sulfonate groups, metal sulfonates might have secondary coordination ability to recognize metal ions. On the basis of these recognition, we created a scheme of two nanoporous cadmium ferrocene-1,1'-disulfonates {[Cd(bpp)2(O3SFcSO3)]⋅(CH3OH)2⋅(H2O)6} n  1 and {[Cd(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]⋅(CH3OH)4} n  2. They show highly selectivity to various divalent metal ions at room temperature, and metal ion sorption take place simultaneously with ion exchange. The solution concentration of metal ions affects the ion sorption and exchange behavior. A possible mechanism of ion sorption and exchange in porous MOFs is proposed. According to this mechanism, the center metal ion-exchange product {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]⋅(CH3OH)4}n 3 was obtained via ion-exchange-induced single crystal to single crystal transformation (see Scheme ).

Ferrocene-1,1′-disulfonate was prepared according to the literature procedure. Other chemicals were of A. R. Grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Fourier Bruker Tensor-27 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm−1 region. Elemental analyses (Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were carried out on a Carlo-Erba 1106 Elemental Analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods

Ferrocene-1,1'-disulfonate was prepared according to the literature procedure. Other chemicals were of A. R. Grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Fourier Bruker Tensor-27 spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. Elemental analyses (Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were carried out on a Carlo-Erba 1106 Elemental Analyzer.

elements.content: A 5 ml solution of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (30.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) in methanol was added to a 5 mL methanol solution of Na2Fc(SO3)2 (39.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), followed by dropwise addition of a 5 mL methanol solution of bridging ligand bpp (39.6 mg, 0.2 mmol). The resulting reaction mixture was stirred for about 10 min and then filtered to give a clear red solution. Slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature gave yellow single crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal analysis in high yield (91%) after 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C38H56CdFeN4O14S2 (%): C, 44.48; H, 5.46; N, 5.46. Found: C, 44.38; H, 5.35; N, 5.52. IR (KBr) (cm−1): 2945w, 1614s, 1559w, 1503w, 1428s, 1225m, 1184s, 1044s, 1016m, 815m, 649s, 613w, 517w, 493s.

elements.content: A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (24.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 5 mL of methanol was treated with big single crystals of 2 (23.70 mg, 0.1 mmol). After being set aside for 30 days, blue transparent crystals were obtained at room temperature. The crystals are easy to effloresce in the air. IR (KBr) (cm−1): 3450s, 1605s, 1535w, 1492s, 1410m, 1385s, 1203s, 809s, 659s, 494s.

After being set aside for 30 days, blue transparent crystals were obtained at room temperature. The crystals are easy to effloresce in the air. elements.content: The measurement of polymer 1 was made on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The measurements of polymers 2 and 3 were made on a MART APEX II CCD diffractometer. All measurements use graphite-monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073Å). The data were collected at a temperature of 18 ± 1°C using the ω–2θ scan technique and corrected for Lorenz-polarization effects. A correction for secondary extinction was applied. The final cycle of full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on observed reflections and variable parameters. All calculations were performed using the SHELXL-97 Program. Crystal data and structure refinement of the three structures are summarized in Table . Main bond lengths and bond angles of 1–3 are listed in Tables –.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The measurement of polymer 1 was made on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The measurements of polymers 2 and 3 were made on a MART APEX II CCD diffractometer. All measurements use graphite-monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073Å). The data were collected at a temperature of 18 ± 1°C using the ω-2θ scan technique and corrected for Lorenz-polarization effects. A correction for secondary extinction was applied. The final cycle of full-matrix least-squares refinement was based on observed reflections and variable parameters. All calculations were performed using the SHELXL-97 Program. Crystal data and structure refinement of the three structures are summarized in Table . Main bond lengths and bond angles of 1-3 are listed in Tables  -.

Sorption isotherm studies of 1 and 2 were performed using a Quantachrome Nova-1000e sorption instrument. As-synthesized crystals of known weight, which were placed in a cylindrical quartz tube (height, 235.5 mm; diameter, 6 mm), were heated at 150°C at 1 × 10−5 Torr for 1.5 h to remove all guest molecules. The N2 gas (UHP grade) was then added incrementally, and the isotherms were recorded at each equilibrium pressure by the static volumetric method. Langmuir surface area and pore volume were estimated using the multipoint Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Measurement

Sorption isotherm studies of 1 and 2 were performed using a Quantachrome Nova-1000e sorption instrument. As-synthesized crystals of known weight, which were placed in a cylindrical quartz tube (height, 235.5 mm; diameter, 6 mm), were heated at 150°C at 1 × 10-5 Torr for 1.5 h to remove all guest molecules. The N2 gas (UHP grade) was then added incrementally, and the isotherms were recorded at each equilibrium pressure by the static volumetric method. Langmuir surface area and pore volume were estimated using the multipoint Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation.

elements.content: The sorption behaviors to divalent metal salts from aqueous solutions were performed using the batchwise method at room temperature. The concentration of the metal ion in solution was determined by atomic sorption spectrometry. The mole number of cations adsorbed and cadmium ions exchanged was also determined on the Z28000 graphite oven atomic sorption spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Metal Ion Sorption and Exchange Measurement

The sorption behaviors to divalent metal salts from aqueous solutions were performed using the batchwise method at room temperature. The concentration of the metal ion in solution was determined by atomic sorption spectrometry. The mole number of cations adsorbed and cadmium ions exchanged was also determined on the Z28000 graphite oven atomic sorption spectrophotometer.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, structural unit of polymer 1 exhibits a petal-shaped geometry. The central Cd(II) ion lies in an elongated octahedral coordination environment [CdN4O2] formed by four nitrogen atoms from four bpp groups and two oxide donors from two monodentate SO3 − groups, respectively. In the block unit, the Cd–N bands range from 2.351(4) to 2.357(4) Å and the distance of Cd–O is 3.361(4) Å. Four N atoms around the central Cd(II) ion from four bpp bridging ligands are coplanar. The main bond angles are O1–Cd–O1a 180°, N1–Cd1–N2a 94.37(15)°, and N1a–Cd1–N2a 85.63(15)°, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

X-ray Crystallography of 1

As shown in Figure a, structural unit of polymer 1 exhibits a petal-shaped geometry. The central Cd(II) ion lies in an elongated octahedral coordination environment [CdN4O2] formed by four nitrogen atoms from four bpp groups and two oxide donors from two monodentate SO3 - groups, respectively. In the block unit, the Cd-N bands range from 2.351(4) to 2.357(4) Å and the distance of Cd-O is 3.361(4) Å. Four N atoms around the central Cd(II) ion from four bpp bridging ligands are coplanar. The main bond angles are O1-Cd-O1a 180°, N1-Cd1-N2a 94.37(15)°, and N1a-Cd1-N2a 85.63(15)°, respectively.

elements.content: The two-dimensional nanoporous network framework of 1 is depicted in Figure b and based on [Cd(bpp)2(SO3FcSO3)] building blocks. The nanometer-sized pores can be easily distinguished from this figure. In this structure, the cadmium atoms locate in the center of the octahedrons, which comprise four nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms. However, the sulphur atoms stand in the peak of the tetrahedrons, which are constructed by a sulphur atom and three conjoining oxygen atoms from sulfonate. Two adjacent Cd(II) cations are bridged by two bpp, forming a double-stranded chain of loops extending along the crystallographic b axis, in which each bpp molecule adopts a trans–gauche conformation and the aromatic rings in opposite are nearly parallel. The size of the loops is measured by the Cd···Cd distance (11.830 Å) and the distance between the middle carbon atoms of the two diametrically opposing ···CH2CH2CH2··· spacers is 8.388 Å. Along the chains formed by ligand −O3SFcSO3 − and the central Cd(II) ion, the separation between the adjacent cadmium ions is 11.072Å. One chain formed by bridge ligands bpp and cadmium ions and the other formed by ligands −O3SFcSO3 − and central Cd(II) ions cross each other, leading to a two dimensional network structure. Among the framework, there are regular parallelogrammic nanosized lattices (11.830×11.072Å2) formed by four adjacent cadmium atoms. The groups of −O3SFcSO3 − act as bifunctional spacers to coordinate the CdN4 complex cations, generating unusual neutral 2D nanoporous network construction.

elements.content: Different from 1, a single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that polymer 2 is a 3D threefold interpenetrated network with molecular formula [Cd(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)] n , which crystallizes in the space group P 21212. As illustrated in Figure a, each Cd(II) cation lays on a crystallographic threefold axis and adopts a slightly distorted octahedral environment by coordinating to four pyridyl groups of four bpy bridging ligands and two −O3SFcSO3 − ligands. The Cd–N bond distances fall in the range of 2.321–2.376 Å, and the Cd-O bond distance is 2.364Å. The main bond angles around the center Cd(II) ions are between 89.00(15) and 179.4(4)°.

elements.content: In coordination polymer 2, there are two types of 4,4′-bipyridine ligands, which are distinguished by their dihedral angles of two pyridine rings (59.2 and 61.5°), and these two pyridine linkers joined with the Cd atoms to form a 2D (4,4) grid network (Figure b). The shortest distances between the two adjacent paralleling linkers in this structure are 11.83 and 13.49 Å, respectively. Simultaneously, −O3SFcSO3 − anions set in the middle of two Cd(II) nodes and the space of Cd···Cd is 13.49 Å. All these gave rise to a 3D threefold interpenetrated network. It should be noted that the shortest distance between two −O3SFcSO3 − is 9.455 Å and the nanocubic channels could be measured as 13.490 × 11.700 × 11.831 Å3.

elements.content: Generally, stable porous coordination networks with large void volumes have been widely employed as gas adsorbents. In this work, the total void volumes, V void, within the crystals of 1 and 2 without solvent guests are, respectively, 25.0 and 53.0% per unit volume, which were calculated by PLATON. Sorption isotherms of N2 gas of polymers 1 and 2 at 77 K are illustrated in Figure . As shown in Figure , 2 can adsorb above five times more nitrogen than 1 per unit, which is close to the total potential solvent accessible void volume of per unit cell of 1 (274.2 Å3) and 2 (988.2 Å3) calculated by PLATON.

Metal Ion Sorption and Exchange Behavior

Generally, stable porous coordination networks with large void volumes have been widely employed as gas adsorbents. In this work, the total void volumes, V void, within the crystals of 1 and 2 without solvent guests are, respectively, 25.0 and 53.0% per unit volume, which were calculated by PLATON. Sorption isotherms of N2 gas of polymers 1 and 2 at 77 K are illustrated in Figure . As shown in Figure , 2 can adsorb above five times more nitrogen than 1 per unit, which is close to the total potential solvent accessible void volume of per unit cell of 1 (274.2 Å3) and 2 (988.2 Å3) calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: Porous MOFs constructed by aryl sulfonates can also be employed as metal ion adsorbents because they exhibit the analogous structures with zeolites. Hence, we utilized 5.0 mg of powdery 1 to measure the percentage of metal ions absorbed of divalent copper salts, lead salts, cobalt salts, nickel salts, manganese salts, and zinc salts in 5 mL of 0.05 mg/mL solutions, using the Z28000 graphite oven atomic sorption spectrophotometer. Figure displays the different sorption behaviors of 1 to these divalent metal salts. Powdery 1 shows the different recognition of different metal ions, even the same metal ions with different anionic sites. For instance, the adsorbed percentage of copper ions with different anionic sites is from 96 to 99% and the adsorbed percentage of lead ions with different anionic parts is between 94 and 96%. Clearly, anionic parts of copper salts or lead salts weakly affect the adsorbed percentage of metal ions. But there are gigantic differences for zinc salts, cobalt salts, nickel salts, and manganese salts with different anionic sites. The adsorbed percentages of zinc ions are 14.98, 50.92, 56.91, and 74.48 (%) with the negative ions Cl−, NO3 −, OAc−, and SO4 2−, respectively. For the negative ion Cl−, the adsorbed percentage of zinc ions is much lower than those of the others. They interact very weakly with the uncoordinated oxygen atoms from −O3SFcSO3 − because the aryl sulfonate groups are thought of as poor ligands.26 The adsorbed percentages of cobalt salts, manganese salts, and nickel salts are between 11.94 and 33.12, 13.71 and 31.33, and 52.31 and 61.07 (%), respectively. The relative uptake values follow the sequence Cu2+ > Pb2+ > Ni2+ > Co2+ ∼ Mn2+ > Zn2+. This agrees well with the previous report, which indicated that the coordination strength of divalent transition metal ions toward the sulfonate group increases in the order of Zn2+ ∼ Co2+ < Cu2+ < Cd2+.27 Obviously, pulverous 1 and 2 could be used to adsorb many metal ions, such as Pb2+, Cu2+, Mn2+, Co2+, and Ni2+. When all these metal ions were mixed in aqueous solution, polymers 1 and 2 selectively adsorb large amount of only Pb2+ (for 1, 88.54%; for 2, 75.80%) and Cu2+ (for 1, 90.94%; for 2, 79.45%). We can find from the above analysis and experiment that the relative uptake values of this polymer accord well with its coordination ability to metal ions. The coordination with transition metal ions results in chemical sorption. Thus, in dilute solutions, chemical sorption may determine the relative mole number of absorbed metal ions in the sorption progress.

elements.content: From the metal ion adsorption behaviors of 1, it is obvious that these kind of complexes have a strong adsorption ability to divalent copper and lead ions. Thus, for the sake of clarifying the ion sorption and exchange behavior of these complexes, their properties of ion sorption and exchange to copper or lead ions are studied in detail. The ion sorption isotherms of 1 and 2 were obtained by using such polymeric ferrocenyl sulfonate adsorbents to adsorb copper and lead ions in 1.0 mg/mL Cu(NO3)2 or Pb(NO3)2 solution at room temperature (Figure ). Both 1 and 2 can absorb nearly the same gross mass of copper ions (2.055 mg for 1 and 2.007 mg for 2) or lead ions (2.794 mg for 1 and 2.797 mg for 2) in 1.0 mg/mL solutions after being stirred for half an hour. The relative mole number of adsorbed copper ions is more than seven times (7.812 equiv for 1 and 7.633 equiv for 2) that of coordinated cadmium ions and far exceeds that of lead ions (4.466 equiv for 1 and 4.471 equiv for 2). The mole numbers of copper and lead ions exceed that of the uncoordinated atoms. The excrescent metal ions may enter into the crystal lattice of the polymers. Meanwhile, the mole ratio of adsorbed Cu2+ and Pb2+ is about 7:3. This result should originate from the difference in ionic radii in all probability. Because the ionic radius of Pb2+ (1.19 Å) is much larger than that of Cu2+ (0.70 Å), it could deposit more copper ions within the same void volume. So, the driving force of this sorption process of metal ion in 1.0 mg/mL solutions should be both chemical action and physical action, i.e., the mole number of adsorbed metal ions in an aqueous solution of 1.0 mg/mL Cu(NO3)2 should be controlled by their coordination ability to unoccupied ferrocenyl sulfonate and their own ionic radii.

elements.content: Ion-exchange properties of porous MOFs are associated closely with their coordination ability. Because of the strong coordination ability of copper or lead ions to unsaturated ferrocenyl sulfonate, copper or lead ions could partly replace the central six-coordinated cadmium ions in polymer 1 or 2. Ion-exchange isotherms of 1 and 2 with Cu(NO3)2 or Pb(NO3)2 in 1.0 mg/mL at room temperature are illustrated in Figure . Obviously, the exchanged cadmium ions in 1 exceeded those in 2 in gross mass, and the solution concentration of exchanged cadmium ions increased with the increase in time. Taking one with another, steric hindrance might be a major factor.

elements.content: The stabilities of polymers 1 and 2 were measured by immersing 30 mg of 1 and 2 into the solutions of 10.0 mg/mL copper ions. As shown in Figure a, analogous IR spectra of 1 and its metal-ion-adsorbed products verified that the coordination polymers retain their structures. The PXRD patterns of 1 and its metal-ion-adsorbed products are presented in Figure b. It is obvious that the main peaks of 1 were also kept in patterns of its Cu2+- and Pb2+-adsorbed products. Meanwhile, the adsorption of Cu2+ or Pb2+ ions produced several new peaks and also made the main peaks of 1 shift a bit.

elements.content: Figure gives the percentages of adsorbed copper ions and the percentages of exchanged cadmium ions in different solution concentrations of Cu(NO3)2. To clearly ascertain the relationship between percentage of exchanged cadmium ions or absorbed copper ions and solution concentration of Cu(NO3)2, we measured the changes of cadmium ions in different solution concentrations of Cu(NO3)2 of 0.025, 0.05, 0.10, 0.25, 0.50, 1.0, 5.0, and 10 mg/mL. Clearly, the percentage of adsorbed copper ions in dilute Cu(NO3)2 solutions is much greater than those in strong solutions; for example, the percentage of adsorbed copper ions is 99.00% for 1 and 99.03% for 2 in 0.05 mg/mL solution, whereas the percentages are 77.98% for 1 and 77.95% for 2 in 5.0 mg/mL solution. Also, the percentage of exchanged cadmium ions comes under the influence of the solution concentration of Cu(NO3)2. Counter to the percentage of adsorbed copper ions, the percentage of exchanged Cd2+ rises with the increase in solution concentration of Cu(NO3)2. For instance, the percentages of exchanged cadmium ions are 12.15% for 1 and 23.65% for 2 in 0.05 mg/mL solution, whereas the percentages are 68.40% for 1 and 66.24% for 2 in 5 mg/mL solution. It is unambiguous to find that with the increase in the solution concentration of Cu(NO3)2, the percentage of adsorbed copper ions is falling, but the percentage of exchanged cadmium ions is rising.

elements.content: Figure gives the gross mass of adsorbed copper ions in different solution concentrations of Cu(NO3)2. Both the gross mass of adsorbed copper ions and exchanged cadmium ions rise with the increase of the solution concentration of Cu(NO3)2. The copper or lead ions could strongly bind to free multifunctional sulfonate groups and thus favor the further reaction, i.e., the interactions among metal ions, −O3SFcSO3 −, and aryl pyridine groups, prompting the whole process of ion exchange and sorption. Processes of ion exchange and sorption between the cadmium ions from two porous polymers and copper or lead ions from aqueous solutions were determined by measuring the changes of the filtered solution concentrations of Cu2+ or Pb2+ and cadmium ions. Cations sorption reaction occurred at room temperature with unusually fast reaction rates, and adsorbed metal ions achieved a constant concentration within only 1 min (Figure 5). However, a central-metal-ion-exchange reaction took place slowly (Figure ). Thus, metal-ion exchange was possibly the rate-determining step of the whole process. And the metal-ion-exchange-induced product {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)] n ·(CH3OH)4} 3 could be obtained by singlecrystaltosinglecrystal transformation from 2.

elements.content: Blue single crystal 3 was obtained after a collection of big yellow single crystals 2 was immersed in a methanol solution of Cu(NO3)2 for 1 month. Photographs of 2′s single crystal in ion-exchange processes were presented in Figure a. In Figure b, Cu2+ ions can replace only part of the Cd2+ ions in polymer 2. 3 performs completely the same molecular structure with 2, except for a slight difference in main bond lengths and bond angles. The atomic sorption detection shows that the Cu2+ occupied 57% of the centers, whereas Cd2+ occupied 43% in 3. Clearly, only ion exchange takes place in the big single crystal because the specific surface area of pulverous polymer is much larger than that of big crystal. Thus, partly exchanged product 3 could be successfully synthesized from big single crystals of 2 after 2 was immersed in the methanol solution of copper ions for about 1 month. This means that metal-organic frameworks with multi-metal-ion centers could be achieved through ion-exchange single crystal to single crystal transformation. Notable that in the synthesis of crystalline solid state materials, an outstanding challenge is to alter chemical composition without changing the underlying topology.29

elements.content: In short, we find and verify the performance that metal ion sorption and central metal ion exchange can take place simultaneity in porous MOF materials. Metal ion sorption and central coordinated metal-ion-exchange behavior in porous metal sulfonate materials is mainly dominated by the coordination ability of metal ions to free functional groups, ionic radii of adsorbed metal ions, steric hindrance, and the solution concentration of adsorbed metal salts. The synthesis of ion-exchange product of 2, {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]·(CH3OH)4} n 3, can furthermore evidence the mechanism of ion sorption and exchange in porous MOFs. This result also has profound potential significance to provide a useful channel in exploration of new medicines, solid state materials, and molecular devices.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In short, we find and verify the performance that metal ion sorption and central metal ion exchange can take place simultaneity in porous MOF materials. Metal ion sorption and central coordinated metal-ion-exchange behavior in porous metal sulfonate materials is mainly dominated by the coordination ability of metal ions to free functional groups, ionic radii of adsorbed metal ions, steric hindrance, and the solution concentration of adsorbed metal salts. The synthesis of ion-exchange product of 2, {[Cd0.5Cu0.5(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]⋅(CH3OH)4} n  3, can furthermore evidence the mechanism of ion sorption and exchange in porous MOFs. This result also has profound potential significance to provide a useful channel in exploration of new medicines, solid state materials, and molecular devices.

A 5 ml solution of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (30.8 mg, 0.1 mmol) in methanol was added to a 5 mL methanol solution of Na2Fc(SO3)2 (39.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), followed by dropwise addition of a 5 mL methanol solution of bridging ligand bpp (39.6 mg, 0.2 mmol). The resulting reaction mixture was stirred for about 10 min and then filtered to give a clear red solution. Slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature gave yellow single crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal analysis in high yield (91%) after 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C38H56CdFeN4O14S2 (%): C, 44.48; H, 5.46; N, 5.46. Found: C, 44.38; H, 5.35; N, 5.52. IR (KBr) (cm−1): 2945w, 1614s, 1559w, 1503w, 1428s, 1225m, 1184s, 1044s, 1016m, 815m, 649s, 613w, 517w, 493s.

Synthesis of {[Cd(bpy)<sub>2</sub>(O<sub>3</sub>SFcSO<sub>3</sub>)]·(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>4</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> 2

The synthetic procedure of 2 is identical to that of 1 (bpy: 31.2 mg, 0.2 mmol). Yellow crystals were deposited within two days (33% yield). Anal. Calcd for C34H40CdFeN4O10S2 (%): C, 45.48; H, 4.46; N, 6.24. Found: C, 45.23; H, 4.25; N, 6.42. IR (KBr) (cm−1): 3438s, 3104w, 1607s, 1537w, 1493w, 1418s, 1226s, 1166s, 1040s, 1010m, 811s, 648s, 489s.

Synthesis of {[Cd<sub>0.43</sub>Cu<sub>0.57</sub>(bpy)<sub>2</sub>(O<sub>3</sub>SFcSO<sub>3</sub>)]·(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>4</sub>}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> 3

A solution of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (24.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 5 mL of methanol was treated with big single crystals of 2 (23.70 mg, 0.1 mmol). After being set aside for 30 days, blue transparent crystals were obtained at room temperature. The crystals are easy to effloresce in the air. IR (KBr) (cm−1): 3450s, 1605s, 1535w, 1492s, 1410m, 1385s, 1203s, 809s, 659s, 494s.

The resulting reaction mixture was stirred for about 10 min and then filtered to give a clear red solution. Slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature gave yellow single crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal analysis in high yield (91%) after 2 weeks. Anal. Calcd for C38H56CdFeN4O14S2 (%): C, 44.48; H, 5.46; N, 5.46. Found: C, 44.38; H, 5.35; N, 5.52. IR (KBr) (cm-1): 2945w, 1614s, 1559w, 1503w, 1428s, 1225m, 1184s, 1044s, 1016m, 815m, 649s, 613w, 517w, 493s.

Synthesis of {[Cd(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]⋅(CH3OH)4} n  2

The synthetic procedure of 2 is identical to that of 1 (bpy: 31.2 mg, 0.2 mmol). Yellow crystals were deposited within two days (33% yield). Anal. Calcd for C34H40CdFeN4O10S2 (%): C, 45.48; H, 4.46; N, 6.24. Found: C, 45.23; H, 4.25; N, 6.42. IR (KBr) (cm-1): 3438s, 3104w, 1607s, 1537w, 1493w, 1418s, 1226s, 1166s, 1040s, 1010m, 811s, 648s, 489s.

Synthesis of {[Cd0.43Cu0.57(bpy)2(O3SFcSO3)]⋅(CH3OH)4} n  3

A solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (24.2 mg, 0.1 mmol) in 5 mL of methanol was treated with big single crystals of 2 (23.70 mg, 0.1 mmol). After being set aside for 30 days, blue transparent crystals were obtained at room temperature. The crystals are easy to effloresce in the air. IR (KBr) (cm-1): 3450s, 1605s, 1535w, 1492s, 1410m, 1385s, 1203s, 809s, 659s, 494s.

cln_elements.content: Generally, stable porous coordination networks with large void volumes have been widely employed as gas adsorbents. In this work, the total void volumes, V void, within the crystals of 1 and 2 without solvent guests are, respectively, 25.0 and 53.0% per unit volume, which were calculated by PLATON. Sorption isotherms of N2 gas of polymers 1 and 2 at 77 K are illustrated in Figure . As shown in Figure , 2 can adsorb above five times more nitrogen than 1 per unit, which is close to the total potential solvent accessible void volume of per unit cell of 1 (274.2 Å3) and 2 (988.2 Å3) calculated by PLATON.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Metal Ion Sorption and Exchange Behavior

Generally, stable porous coordination networks with large void volumes have been widely employed as gas adsorbents. In this work, the total void volumes, V void, within the crystals of 1 and 2 without solvent guests are, respectively, 25.0 and 53.0% per unit volume, which were calculated by PLATON. Sorption isotherms of N2 gas of polymers 1 and 2 at 77 K are illustrated in Figure . As shown in Figure , 2 can adsorb above five times more nitrogen than 1 per unit, which is close to the total potential solvent accessible void volume of per unit cell of 1 (274.2 Å3) and 2 (988.2 Å3) calculated by PLATON.
